contextId.information: This is a rhetorical question that a father would ask to discipline his son. AT: "You should know that what you have done is wrong." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why have you done this or that?

contextId.information: The purpose of this question is to introduce the information that Nathan wants to tell Bathsheba. AT: "You do not seem to have heard ... it." or "Have you heard ... it?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not heard ... it?

contextId.information: The purpose of this question was to remind David of what he had promised Bathsheba. AT: "you swore to your servant ... throne." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: did you not swear to your servant ... throne?

contextId.information: King Solomon was angered by his mother's request. AT: "You are wrong to ask ... Adonijah! This is the same as asking the kingdom for him also ... Zeruiah!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you ask ... Adonijah? Why do you not ask the kingdom for him also ... Zeruiah?

contextId.information: Solomon is reminding Shimei of what Shimei had promised. AT: "You know very well that I made you swear ... saying, 'Know ... die'!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did I not make you swear ... saying, 'Know ... die'?

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Solomon is asking for an answer or 2) AT: "You have done wrong by breaking your oath ... you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why then have you not kept your oath ... you?

contextId.information: Possible meanings of this question are 1) Solomon is asking a real question and expecting an answer or 2) the question is rhetorical and Solomon is emphasizing that God is too big and mighty to live on earth. AT: But it surely cannot be that God will actually live on the earth!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But will God actually live on the earth?

contextId.information: Hiram is rebuking Solomon. AT: "These cities that you have given me are good for nothing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What cities are these which you have given me, my brother?

contextId.information: This question shows that Ahijah knew she was disguised. AT: "Stop pretending to be someone else; I know who you are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you pretend to be someone you are not?

contextId.information: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Abijah is in this other book. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:29|14:29]]. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: are they not written in the book of the events of the kings of Judah?

See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:31|15:31]]. AT: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: are they not written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel?

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Elijah is truly asking a question. AT: "why would you cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" or 2) Elijah uses a question to express how sad he is. AT: "surely, you would not cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: have you also brought disaster on the widow with whom I am staying, by killing her son?

contextId.information: Obadiah asks this question to emphasize the danger to himself because of King Ahab's anger at Elijah. AT: "I have not wronged you ... for him to kill me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How have I sinned ... for him to kill me?

contextId.information: Ahab asks the question for emphasis to be certain about Elijah's identity. AT: "So here you are. You are the troublemaker of Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it you? You are the one who brings trouble to Israel!

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question to emphasize the size and strength of Ben Hadad's army. AT: "Look at this great army." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you seen this great army?

contextId.information: Ahab asks this question to express surprise. AT: "I am surprised that he is still alive!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is he still alive?

contextId.information: Jezebel uses this negative rhetorical question to rebuke Ahab. It can be translated as a positive statement. AT: "You still rule the kingdom of Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not still rule the kingdom of Israel?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question to scold Ahab. AT: "You have killed Naboth and stolen his vineyard!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you killed and also taken possession?

contextId.information: Ahab uses this question to express anger toward Elijah. That Elijah "found" Ahab likely refers to Elijah discovering Ahab's actions, not to finding his physical location. AT: "You have found me, my enemy!" or "You have discovered what I have done, my enemy!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Have you found me, my enemy?

contextId.information: Ahab asks this question to emphasize that they should have already recaptured Ramoth Gilead. AT: "Ramoth Gilead is ours, but we have done nothing yet to take it from the hand of the king of Aram." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you know that Ramoth Gilead is ours, but that we are doing nothing to take it from the hand of the king of Aram?

contextId.information: Ahab asks this question out of frustration to rebuke Micaiah. AT: "Many times I have required ... in the name of Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How many times must I require ... in the name of Yahweh?

contextId.information: Ahab asks this question to emphasize that he had spoken the truth about Micaiah. AT: "I told you ... but only disaster!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did I not tell you ... but only disaster?

contextId.information: Zedekiah asks this sarcastic question to insult and rebuke Micaiah. AT: "Do not think that Yahweh's Spirit left me to speak to you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which way did the Spirit of Yahweh take to go from me to speak to you?
